title: Developer Nile Niami Lists $65 Million Bel Air, Los Angeles, Home
text:
The Los Angeles developer behind the most expensive listing in the U.S. has unveiled another gargantuan new build in Bel Air, asking a comparatively modest $65 million.



Nile Niami—a former film producer whose firm Skyline Development is behind a Bel Air spec home with an ambitious $500 million price tag—put his latest project on the market on Monday. It clocks in at about half the size of the White House with nearly 30,000 square feet of interior space plus an 160-foot swimming pool (nearly Olympic in length).



More: Sotheby’s to Offer Francis Bacon’s ‘Pope’ on Behalf of Brooklyn Museum

This is the third spec home Skyline Development has created with architect Paul McClean, who also designed the firm’s $500 million listing and Opus, another glass-and-slab-stone-filled project in Beverly Hills, asking $80 million.



This latest contemporary megalith channels a similar energy to the duo’s other collaborations: Voluminous rooms dressed in steely achromatic materials warmed by heaps of sunlight pouring through floor-to-ceiling glass, according to images of the new listing.



There are nine bedrooms in total, including a master suite with skylit dressing rooms, a sizable morning kitchen and a large lounge area.



The developer likened the two-story Bel Air mansion to “your own private resort,” Mr. Niami said.



Amenities include a hair salon, home cinema, fitness center and wellness spa that includes separate rooms for massages, facials and yoga, according to the listing with Jennifer Priel and Aaron Kirman, both of Compass.



The setting also offers “complete seclusion” tucked away “in the middle of prime Bel Air,” Ms. Priel said.



The 1.5-acre property also has 20 parking spaces, an outdoor kitchen and a 30-foot waterfall wall, according to the listing.



More: Paul Allen’s Silicon Valley Home Lists for Just Under $41.5 Million

The past two weeks have seen a flurry of new listings on Los Angeles’s pricey Westside asking north of $60 million.

So far this month, Michael Chow, the restaurateur behind Mr. Chow, re-listed a villa in nearby Holmby Hills for just shy of $70 million, while the former Spanish-style pile of Rams owner Georgia Frontiere also hit the market for $75 million. So did a brand new modern construction in Beverly Hills and the home of “Diehard” filmmaker Joel Silver, who’s asking $77 million.
